Sure, here are some websites and resources that you might find helpful:

1. The American Gastroenterological Association (AGA) has an informative webpage on the gut microbiome and its importance to health: https://www.gastro.org/practice-guidance/gi-patient-center/topic/microbiome. 2. The International Scientific Association for Probiotics and Prebiotics (ISAPP) is a non-profit organization dedicated to promoting scientific evidence regarding probiotics, prebiotics, and fermented foods. You can find several resources on their website: https://isappscience.org/. 3. Wild Fermentation by Sandor Ellix Katz is an excellent book on fermentation that teaches recipes, techniques, and history of cultured foods. You'll learn how to make sourdough bread, kefir, miso, kimchi, and much more. 4. Nourishing Traditions by Sally Fallon is a well-regarded cookbook that presents recipes in the context of the Weston A. Price Foundation, a nonprofit nutrition education organization. The book includes recipes for cooking traditional, unprocessed foods, including cultured and fermented vegetables and dairy products. 5. Cultures for Health is a website that specializes in fermentation supplies and educational resources. They offer advice on choosing starter cultures, troubleshooting fermentation problems, and finding recipes. By educating yourself about gut health and fermentation processes, you can make informed decisions about the foods you consume and improve your overall health and wellbeing.
